Graphical abstract A novel series of copper catalysts with multiple active sites, coordinated by AcGlu and 2-methyl-imidazolium were presented. The multi-active site catalyst, Im-Cu A, facilitates the simultaneous capture and activation of CO2 and propargylamine, achieving an outstanding TOF of 880 h−1. Notably, its catalytic efficiency remains stable over 20 cycles. Spectroscopic techniques and DFT reveal Im-Cu A orchestrates synergistic activation of inert CO2 and propargylic amine, promoting carboxylative cyclization. The conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2) and propargylamines to 2-oxazolidinones is an essential reaction in industry, but efficiently activating both feedstocks remains a huge challenge for majority of catalysts. Herein, we developed a long-term stable copper catalyst, co-coordinated with sugar acetates (acetylglucose, AcGlu) and 2-methyl-imidazolium (Im-Cu A). This catalyst features multi-active site, enabling it to efficiently capture and activate CO2, activate propargylamines, and stabilize the catalyst species simultaneously. As expected, 2-oxazolidinone was synthesized by this cyclization reaction with an exciting turnover frequency of 880 h−1, which is around 180 times higher than that of CuCl2. Moreover, the catalytic activity of Im-Cu A did not decrease even after 20 replicates, which is exceptionally rare for homogeneous catalysts. Density functional theory calculations indicate that the electron-donating AcGlu and 2-methyl-imidazolium units facilitate electrons transport from Im-Cu A to CO2. Moreover, the high electron density of AcGlu and 2-methyl-imidazolium groups is believed to play a crucial role in the long-term stability across various temperatures and excellent catalytic performance of Im-Cu A. This represents a significant advancement in the development of a highly stable copper catalyst with multi-active site that effectively activates all reaction substrates. This strategy could improve the development of metal catalysts with sustained superior performance for CO2 conversion. Keywords Catalysis Non-noble metal catalyst Imidazolium copper salt Acetylglucose derivatives Carbon dioxide Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Excessive emissions of carbon dioxide (CO2) from industry is one of the major sources for global warming [1,2]. Converting inert CO2 into heterocyclic compounds is one of the promising strategies for reducing CO2 emission and achieving a perfect carbon neutrality but it is usually catalyzed by noble-metal-based materials (e.g., Pd, Au, Ru, and Ag) [3–7]. In particular, 2-oxazolidinone derivatives have important application potential in antibacterial agents, chemical intermediates, and chiral auxiliaries [8–11]. Recognized, the most ideal and eco-friendly chemical synthesis of 2-oxazolidinone heterocyclic compounds is the carboxylative cyclization of CO2 and propargylamines [12–16]. The innate low reactivity and kinetic inertness of CO2 is due to its classical π 3 4 delocalized electronic structure, therefore, noble metal catalyst, high pressure, high temperature, co-catalyst usually required in its chemical transformation [17,18]. From a practical viewpoint, directly transforming simulated flue gas (CO2 concentration 15 %–30 %) into valuable products should be an optimal alternative, as it can circumvent the high energy costs of separating and concentrating anthropogenic CO2 [19,20]. Additionally, due to the unique structure of propargylamines, which contains NH, C≡CH, ArCH2, and C≡CCH2 groups, it is difficult for most reported catalysts to achieve this conversion with satisfactory high-performance [21]. Based on the above challenges, the realization of high catalytic activity, high recyclability, especially low cost catalyst is difficult for scientific researchers. Therefore, there is an urgent need to formulate a high-efficiency non-noble-metal-based materials (e.g., Fe, Co, Cu, and Zn), which possesses multi-active site for the preparation of 2-oxazolidinone derivatives from absorption/activation CO2, activation propargylamines, and stabilization metal catalyst species under mild conditions. Featuring the traits of high-activity, low-cost, and eco-friendliness, Cu catalyst displays magnetic application prospects in the field of CO2 conversion [22–28]. Most recently, wang and coworkers present an efficient heterogeneous CuI@TpBD-COF for the reaction between propargylamine and CO2 to produce oxazolidinone with a TOF up to 1058 h−1 [29]. As known, homogeneous catalyst often suffer from the separation from reaction system and recycling of the catalyst [30,31]. Tunable ionic liquids (ILs) have been applied in various organic syntheses as either catalyst or solvent, and could be easy to recycle after removing the starting materials and products [32,33]. Meanwhile, ILs catalyst have been widely investigated in CO2 chemical conversion because of their high absorption capacity and solubility for CO2 [34,35]. Among them, task-specific imidazolium-based ILs with clear active sites and unique electronic structure have been documented for CO2 capture/activation [36–38], and metal catalytic species stabilization [39,40]. Sugar acetates with acetyl (Ac, CH3 C = O) groups are emerging as a promising class of extraordinarily CO2-philic material with wide applications [41,42]. Due to the manifold electron donor sites of oxygen atoms, the interactions between sugar and metal are available and critical [43,44]. The direct catalytic conversion of CO2 to organic chemicals, as proposed in our previous reports [45–47], and other research groups [16,21], facilitates the simultaneous capture, activation, and conversion of CO2. However, the underlying mechanisms responsible for the improved catalytic activity require further investigation. As an alternative greener catalyst, metal-containing ILs with multi-active site provide the perfect platform for designing new multifunctional catalysts. Thus, introducing both sugar acetates and 2-methyl-imidazolium cations can be expected to achieve the CO2 capture/activation, propargylamine activation, metal catalytic species stabilization, and subsequent transformation effectively. Along this idea, we designed a AcGlu and 2-methyl-imidazolium co-coordinated copper catalyst (Im-Cu A) with multi-active site for the activation of CO2, propargylamine, and stabilization of Cu catalytically active species. This catalyst integrates the functions of AcGlu, 2-methyl-imidazolium-based ILs, and earth-abundant metal Cu for accelerating the conversion of CO2 and propargylamines to 2-oxazolidinones. AcGlu-hydrolysis 2-methyl-imidazolium (Glu, Im-Cu B), benzimidazolium (Im-Cu C), and AcGlu-free benzimidazolium ( n Octyl, Im-Cu D) catalysts are synthesized in parallel for in-depth research. As expected, Im-Cu A presents superior catalytic performance with a maximum TOF of 880 h−1, significantly surpassing most reported Cu catalysts. Additionally, Im-Cu A exhibits good stability across various temperatures and maintains high cyclicity over 20 times without significant loss in catalytic activity. The AcGlu units and 2-methyl-imidazolium cations serve as LA-LB coordination sites for the activation of CO2 and simultaneous stabilization of the Cu catalytic centers. Meanwhile, the high-performance catalytic system for the activation of protons (NH, C≡CH, ArCH2, and C≡CCH2) in propargylamine ensures smooth and efficient catalytic conversion. Catalytic mechanisms were investigated throughout by 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra, 13C-isotope labeling experiments, and density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Both experimental and theoretical results confirmed that AcGlu and 2-methyl-imidazolium co-coordinated Im-Cu A with multiple LA-LB sites for the activation of CO2, propargylamine, and stabilization of Cu catalyst species. More importantly, the development of high-performance catalysts possessing all functions including activation and conversion is meaningful for the reaction of CO2 and propargylamine. The AcGlu and 2-methyl-imidazolium co-coordinated catalyst with multiple LA-LB sites holds great promise for the realization of the on-site sustainable chemistry rooted in CO2 utilization. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and characterization Chemical reagents were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. and Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., and were used as received unless otherwise noted. Nitrogen gas (N2, 99.999 %) and dilute CO2 gas (CO2/N2, Vol/Vol = 15:85) were supplied by Ganzhou Shengda Gas Co., Ltd. Flash column chromatography was performed using silica gel (300–400 mesh) as the stationary phase. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance III 400 NMR spectrometer, with chemical shift (δ) reported in parts per million (ppm). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were collected using an Avatar Nicolet spectrometer in neat conditions with smart OMNI-transmission accessories or potassium bromide (KBr) pellets, with frequencies expressed in wavenumbers (cm−1). Liquid chromatography/high-resolution mass spectrometry (LC/HR-MS) analyses were conducted on an LCMS-9030 system (Shimadzu Corporation), with samples prepared in either methanol (MeOH) or acetonitrile (CH3CN). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using an Axis Ultra DLD (Kratos Analytical Ltd.) spectrometer, employing monochromatized Al Kα radiation as the X-ray source. The gas proportioner (model KT-C3ZS) was manufactured by Zhengzhou Ketan Instrument Equipment Co., Ltd. Thermal stability of Im-Cu A-D was investigated via thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), using a NETZSCH TG 209 at a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1 under a nitrogen atmosphere. 2.2 Rational design and synthesis of Im-Cu catalysts Im-Cu A-D As illustrated in Scheme 1, β-glucose pentaacetate (PGA) was synthesized from D-glucose utilizing iodine (I2) as a catalyst. The production of 2-bromoethyl glucoside (R*-Br) was achieved through the reaction between PGA and bromoethanol, employing boron trifluoride etherate (BF3·OEt2) as a catalyst. This intermediate subsequently underwent a reaction with N-alkylated bis(imidazole) derivatives, yielding pale-yellow solid compounds (Im-Br 1–3) [45–47]. The reaction of Im-Br 1–3 with a mixture of CuCl2·2H2O and NaCl resulted in the formation of yellow-orange microcrystalline precipitates Im-Cu A-C [48]. Specifically, Im-Cu B was scrutinized to assess the influence of Ac-protecting groups during the catalytic reaction. Two synthetic routes were explored for the preparation of Im-Cu B with Glu groups (Scheme 1b). Similarly, Im-Cu D, characterized by n Octyl ( n C8H17-) groups, was synthesized to examine its impact on the catalytic process (Fig. S1). 2.3 Preparation of Im-Cu B with two routes Route I. Im-Br 1 (0.5 mmol) was dissolved in anhydrous MeOH (10 mL) and treated with a catalytic amount of freshly prepared sodium methoxide (NaOMe) to generate a basic environment (pH ∼ 9) (Scheme 1b). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. Subsequent neutralization was accomplished using dry Amberlite IR 120 (H+) resin to reach a pH of ∼7. The crude product was then washed with NaHCO3, NaCl, and DI water. Solvent evaporation afforded the final product, Im-Cu B, in 95 % yield. Route II. Im-Cu B was synthesized from Im-Br 1 through the removal of Ac-protective groups to elucidate their role in the catalytic process. Im-Br 1 (0.04 mmol) was dissolved in anhydrous MeOH (10 mL) and incrementally treated with freshly prepared NaOMe (0.4 mmol) under ice-cooling. The mixture was stirred for 12 h at approximately 20 °C to maintain a pH of 9 (Scheme 1b). Subsequent neutralization was accomplished using dry Amberlite IR 120 (H+) resin, adjusting the pH to 7. During this process, the solution color changed from light yellow to chartreuse, accompanied by minor solid precipitation (Fig. S2). 2.4 General procedure for Cu-catalyzed carboxylative cyclization reaction of CO2 and propargylamines CO2 as C1 source. In a standard procedure, Im-Cu A (0.25–0.5 mol%), propargylamine 5a (0.05 mmol), and K2CO3 (0.075 mmol) were combined in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, 1.0 mL) within a reaction vessel. A simulated flue gas (CO2/N2, Vol/Vol = 15:85, bubbling) was bubbled into the preheated reaction mixture using a long hollow needle (φ 0.7 × 200 mm) immersed in a 80 °C oil bath. The reaction mixture was then stirred for a specified duration. The yield was quantified using 1H NMR spectroscopy. To determine the isolated yields of purified products, the crude material was concentrated and subjected to purification via column chromatography on silica gel using a gradient elution of petroleum ether/ethyl acetate (V:V = 20:1 to 10:1). The isolated yields were calculated based on the initial reactants. The synthesis of 13C labeled 2-oxazolidinone involving 13CO2 follows a similar procedure. 13CO2 (99.999 %, stored in a 1.0 l airbag) was bubbled into the preheated reaction mixture instead of simulated flue gas. 2.5 General procedure for the Im-Cu-catalyzed recycling of carboxylative cyclization reaction Im-Cu A or Im-Cu B (0.25 mol%), propargylamine 5a (0.1 mmol), and K2CO3 (0.3 mmol) were combined in DMSO (1.0 mL). A simulated flue gas (CO2/N2, Vol/Vol = 15:85, bubbling) was bubbled into the preheated reaction mixture immersed in an 80 °C oil bath for 5.0 min. After each catalytic cycle, the product was extracted three times with ethyl acetate, and fresh propargylamine 5a was added to the catalytic system (Fig. 2 a). Yields were determined by 1H NMR (Fig. 2b). Photos of selected catalytic system were presented in Fig. 2c. Finally, the solvent was removed by freeze-drying to recover the catalyst. 2.6 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations DFT calculations were performed by using the Dmol3 module implanted in Materials Studio software. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with Perdew-Becke-Ernzerhof (PBE) was used for the exchange–correlation functional to optimize the structures. The DFT-D method was used on GGA-PBE model to account for the dispersion correction. The solvent effect of DMSO‑d6 was considered by using the conductor-like screening model (COSMO) on the Dmol3 calculation. The convergence tolerance of energy, maximum force, maximum displacement, maximum iterations and maximum step size were set as 1 × 10−5 Ha, 0.002 Ha·Å, 0.05 Å, 1000 and 0.3 Å, respectively. Double numerical plus polarization (DNP) functions were adopted as the basis set. The linear/quadratic synchronous transit (LST/QST) approach was used to study the transition states of the reaction pathway, and frequency analyses were used to validate the optimized transition state structures. The energy barriers of the various reactions were calculated by subtracting the energies of the initial states from the energies of transition states. 3 Results and discussion The designed Im-Cu A-D demonstrated enhanced solubility in polar organic solvents—including MeOH, ethanol, DMSO, and dimethylformamide (DMF)—attributable to the extensive hydrogen bonding between the chloride ions of the tetrachlorocuprate (CuCl4 2−) anion and the protons from the imidazolium heterocycle [49]. The structures of these intermediates and Im-Cu catalysts were confirmed by NMR spectroscopy, Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, and liquid chromatography/high resolution-mass spectrometry (LC/HR-MS). 1H and 13C NMR spectra of Im-Cu A-D are similar to those of the corresponding Im-Br 1–4, which may be due to the rapid hydrogen transfer of the imidazolium ring [47,50]. The C2CH3 in the 2-methyl-imidazolium heterocycle of Im-Cu A appears at 2.65 ppm in 1H NMR and 11.0 ppm in 13C NMR, confirming the existence of C(sp3)–H and sp3–C. Indeed, the distorted tetrahedral CuCl4 2− anions can be formed in the corresponding Im-Cu A-D [48]. FT-IR spectra reveal that Im-Cu A-D exhibit a characteristic v (NCN) absorption band within 1375–1430 cm−1. Notably, the absorption signals at 1725 and 1590 cm−1 are attributed to the vibrational modes of C = C and C = N within the imidazolium ring. From the LC/HR-MS analyses in the positive ion mode identified the imidazolium cations distinctly, with identical signals observed for both Im-Br 1–4 and their corresponding Im-Cu A-D. During the synthesis of Im-Cu B via Route II, the gradual addition of freshly prepared sodium methoxide to the anhydrous MeOH solution of Im-Cu A—originally light yellow—resulted in a color transition to light green and subsequently chartreuse (Fig. S2). This was followed by neutralization using acidic ion-exchange resins, leading to the observation of solid precipitation. As observed in the survey X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra (Fig. S3), C, N, O, and Cu are revealed to be the main components of these designed samples. The binding energies of Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2 of Im-Cu A are located at 953.5 and 933.6 eV (Fig. S3a). The Cu 2p spectrum of Im-Cu B shows two couples of fitted peaks assigned to copper (II) (954.4 and 935.3 eV). The O 1s XPS spectrum revealed a pronounced peak at 533.2 eV for carboxylate oxygen in Im-Cu A, enriched with Ac-protecting units, and a newly emergent peak at 532.4 eV, indicative of hydroxyl oxygen, in Im-Cu B lacking Ac-protecting groups (Fig. S3c). The color change and XPS data collectively suggest that Ac-protecting groups contribute to the stabilization of CuCl4 2− ions. The TGA curves indicate that the decomposition temperatures of catalysts Im-Cu A-D range from 140 °C to 285 °C (Fig. S4), demonstrating their good thermal stability. Additionally, Im-Cu A was dissolved in DMSO‑d6 and maintained at various temperatures (−30 °C, 10 °C, and 80 °C) for 10 h to evaluate its stability in solution (Fig. S5). Notably, no significant changes were observed in its 1H, 13C NMR spectra. In contrast, upon heating Im-Cu B to 80 °C (Fig. S6), the signal peak of the sugar ring in 1H NMR spectrum broadened significantly (Fig. S6a), indicating reduced stability in the absence of Ac- groups. 3.1 Catalytic performances of Im-Cu catalysts To evaluate the catalytic activity of Im-Cu A-D, the reaction conditions are investigated thoroughly. As shown in Table 1 and Tables S1–S4, potassium carbonate (K2CO3), DMSO, and 80 ℃ are found to be the optimal base, solvent, and temperature for the model reaction of CO2 and N-[[4-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl]-methyl]prop-2-yn-1-amine (5a) to prepare 5-methylene-3-(4-(trifluoromethyl)-benzyl)-oxazolidin-2-one (6a) by employing catalyst Im-Cu A (Equation 1, Table 1, entry 1). Then, Im-Cu B, C, and D were evaluated with the same Cu dosage as Im-Cu A (entries 1–4), in which Im-Cu A exhibits the highest catalytic activity and record TOF reaching 880 h−1 with 86 % yield (entry 1). AcGlu groups endowed Im-Cu C (665 h−1) and Im-Cu A with significantly higher TOF values than Im-Cu D (462 h−1) with n octyl groups (entries 1, 3, and 4). The catalytic activity of Im-Cu B with Glu units without Ac-protecting groups was significantly lower than that of Im-Cu A, and provided a yield of 45 % with a TOF of 450 h−1 (entry 2), indicated that Ac-protecting groups in AcGlu units play an important role herein. As expected, target product 6a could not be detected without Cu catalyst (entry 5). The low TOF values of 4.9, 2.5, and 3.9 h−1 were obtained with the purchased copper catalysts including CuCl2, Cu(NO3)2, and CuI, respectively (Table S4, entries 1–3). In contrast, Im-Br 1:CuCl2·2H2O (mol:mol = 1:1) exhibited a relatively higher TOF value of 57 h−1 with 87 % yield than the purchased copper catalysts, confirm that Im-Br 1 could enhance the catalytic performance (entry 4). When Im-Br 1 or R*-Br was used, no product obtained (entry 5), as anticipated, the reaction did not occur in the absence of a base even added Im-Br 1/Im-Cu A together (entry 6), demonstrated that copper remains the real catalytic core. The TOF value of Im-Cu A is around 180 times higher than that of CuCl2. The TOF value of Im-Cu A was compared with previously Cu catalytic systems (Table S5), Im-Cu A outperforms all other homogeneous Cu catalytic systems for carboxylative cyclization of CO2 with propargylamines. All these results confirmed the synergistic catalytic effect between AcGlu units, 2-methyl-imidazolium cations, and CuCl4 2− anions, which endowes Im-Cu A a high catalytic ability in CO2 conversion. The substrate scope of various propargylamines (Fig. 1, 5a–5l) with CO2 (0.15 bar, bubbling) were investigated by employing Im-Cu A as catalyst under the optimal reaction conditions. Most of terminal propargylamines (Fig. 1, 5a–5f and 5i–5l) could be converted into the corresponding target products with excellent yields (6a-6f and 6i-6l, ca. 100 %). The substituted substrates with electron-donating or withdrawing groups on the N-benzyl moiety were tolerated well and gave 2-oxazolidinones in excellent yields (96–100 %). Additionally, the yields of 6g and 6h are only 36 % and 45 %, respectively, due to significant steric effects. However, the yields can reach approximately 100 % by extending the reaction time to 30 min. These results confirm that Im-Cu A is a highly efficient catalyst for the conversion of CO2 and propargylamines. Notably, the Im-Cu A-catalyzed conversion of 5a and CO2 produced gram-scale 6a with an approximate yield of 93 % (1.078 g, Fig. S8). The catalytic recyclability and performances of catalyst Im-Cu A was further investigated. The catalytic activity of Im-Cu A remained unchanged after 20 successive runs, in which ca. 100 % NMR yield was still obtained (Fig. 2a and b), and the color of the catalytic system was almost unchanged during the overall cycle evaluation (Fig. 2c). The catalytic recyclability of Im-Cu B lacking Ac-protecting groups is much lower, whose yield decreased below 90 % just after acceptable 5 runs (Fig. 2a). Pohl and coworkers found that increasing numbers of Ac-protecting units in sugar enhance the binding strength towards divalent copper cation [51]. Herein, the Ac-protecting groups increases the LA-LB and hydrogen bonding interactions with CuCl4 2−, and then enhances the stability of copper catalytic species during the catalytic process. Notably, no significant changes were observed in the 1H and 13C NMR spectra or in color between fresh and used Im-Cu A across different environments (Fig. S10). These results indicate that Im-Cu A is stable and does not decompose during the catalytic reaction. 3.2 Mechanistic insights into Im-Cu A-assisted reaction process The plausible reaction process and real active sites were uncovered with 1H NMR. The D2O exchange experiment of 5a present in Fig. S11, the NH (2.74 ppm) and HOH (3.33 ppm) can be efficiently recognized. We find that the characteristic peaks of 5a (2.25, 3.47, and 3.94 ppm) gradually decreased with increasing reaction time, the newly formed ArCH2 (I′, 4.54 ppm), NCH2 C (II′, 4.02 ppm), and C = CH2 (III′, 4.25 and 4.75 ppm) peaks from product 6a increased (Fig. 3 a). These changes suggested that the NH group of 5a reacted with CO2 to form carbamate, which was further transferred to the product 6a [26]. Moreover, we conducted relevant control experiments to gain more insight into the fundamental source of Im-Cu A. Firstly, K2CO3, CO2, and 5a were used to determine the respective contributions of CuCl4 2−, AcGlu, and 2-methyl-imidazolium units during Im-Cu A-catalyzed reaction. Activation of 5a was explored by adding Im-Cu A and K2CO3 separately or simultaneously (Fig. 3b). The signals of ArCH2 (I, 3.82 ppm), C≡CCH2 (II, 3.29 ppm), and NH (IV, 2.74 ppm) became weak, broad, and almost vanished, demonstrated that these protons can be strongly activated after Im-Cu A was added. When K2CO3 was introduced, the singlet signal from proton I split into a doublet peak at 3.82 (d, J = 8.0 Hz) ppm, the signal from proton II split from a doublet peak into a quartet peak at 3.29 (dd, J1 = 8.0 Hz, J2 = 4.0 Hz) ppm, and the singlet signal from proton IV split into a multiple-peak, indicated that K2CO3 could also activate 5a. When Im-Cu A and K2CO3 were added simultaneously, the singlet signal of proton I split into a doublet peak at 3.82 (d, J = 4.0 Hz) ppm, and the peak of proton II became broad, indicated that these protons can be synergistically activated by Im-Cu A and K2CO3, which was favorable for the formation of an intermediate for further reaction with CO2. The signal of C≡CH (III, 3.11 ppm) remained unchanged when Im-Cu A and K2CO3 were added alone or together, indicated that this proton III cannot be activated here. The signal of proton IV become broad when Im-Cu A and K2CO3 were added, indicated that proton IV can be activated, which was consistent with the activation sites (III and IV) described previously in literatures [25,52]. CO2 was bubbled into the DMSO‑d6 solution of Im-Cu A to uncover the interaction sites between them (Fig. 3c). The chemical shift (δ) of the imidazolium heterocycle and Ac- protons move high-field by 8.6 Hz and 2.0–3.6 Hz at RT. Upon heating to 50 ℃ for 1.0 h, the δ for 2-methyl-imidazolium heterocycle protons increased to 10.8 Hz, while that for Ac- protons narrowed to 0.5–1.6 Hz. These changes underscore the pivotal roles of 2-methyl-imidazolium and Ac-protecting moieties in CO2 capture and activation. To further elucidate the interactions between CO2 and catalytic systems, CO2 was bubbled through a DMSO‑d6 solution of Im-Cu A/K2CO3 (Fig. 3d), resulting in δ of 4.0 Hz for 2-methyl-imidazolium protons and 1.6–2.0 Hz for Ac- protons. Prolonged heating under these conditions left the signals of most AcGlu units unaltered, indicating robust interactions between CO2 and AcGlu units. The influence of K2CO3 on the catalytic system was elucidated through its addition to the DMSO‑d6 solution of Im-Cu A, as evidenced by the upfield shift of 15.0 Hz for imidazolium protons and 0.3–1.5 Hz for Ac- protons (Fig. S12), suggesting an interaction with Im-Cu A. Similarly, incorporating K2CO3 into the DMSO‑d6 solution of Im-Cu A/CO2 resulted in upfield shifts of 5.5 and 11.0–12.6 Hz for 2-methyl-imidazolium and Ac- protons, respectively, with the peaks becoming weaker and broader, indicative of strong interactions between K2CO3 and the Im-Cu A/CO2 (Fig. 4a, S13, and S14). Conversely, the addition of Im-Cu A to the DMSO‑d6 solution of 5a led to downfield shifts of 4.0–5.2 Hz for both 2-methyl-imidazolium and Ac- protons (Fig. 4b and S15), demonstrating significant interactions between them. These observations confirm the critical role of 2-methyl-imidazolium heterocycle and AcGlu units within Im-Cu A as LA-LB sites for CO2 adsorption and activation, and in stabilizing the active copper site during the carboxylative cyclization of CO2 with propargylamines. The 13C-isotope labeling experiments were conducted to trace the carbon source in the synthesis of 2-oxazolidinone using 13CO2. Post-reaction between 5a and 13CO2, 13C NMR spectra revealed a pronounced increase in the intensity of the carbonyl (C = O) signal at 155.6 ppm in the labeled product 6a, relative to its unlabeled counterpart (Fig. 4 c). This enhancement confirms the successful incorporation of 13CO2 into the 2-oxazolidinone framework. The FT-IR spectrum of the 13C-labeled 6a exhibited a distinctive blue-shift of 25 cm−1 (from 1758 to 1783 cm−1) compared to the unlabeled one (Fig. 4d), indicative of the primary vibration of the O=13CO bond. These combined 13C-isotope labeling NMR and FT-IR spectroscopic analyses unequivocally demonstrate the precise conversion of CO2 and propargylamine into 2-oxazolidinone. The synergistical activation effects of CO2, propargylamine, and stabilization of Cu catalytic species were further confirmed by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. A CuCl4 2− was used as a model, anchored by the U-shaped bis(2-methyl-imidazolium) cations with strongly interlocking AcGlu units (Fig. 5 a). The adsorption energy of CuCl4 2− in Im-Cu A was calculated to be 1.49 eV, which is higher than that in Im-Cu B (1.36 eV), indicating that the AcGlu units in Im-Cu A is favorable for the stabilization of CuCl4 2−. After examining various sites of Im-Cu A and Im-Cu B, five stable structures were obtained for binding CO2 with Im-Cu A and Im-Cu B, including N, Cl, Cu, O1 and O2 sites (Fig. S16 and S17). This confirmed that the N site on imidazolium heterocycle is the most favorable site for CO2 adsorption on Im-Cu A and Im-Cu B catalysts [36,40]. The differences in the charge density of Im-Cu A and Im-Cu B are also shown in Fig. 5a. After the modification of Im-Cu with AcGlu groups, the charge density distribution of Im-Cu A molecular is clearly different from that of Im-Cu B without Ac-protecting groups. After adsorption of CO2, the electron density of the imidazolium heterocycle on Im-Cu A is lower than that on Im-Cu B (Fig. 5a), which means that more electrons are transferred from Im-Cu A to CO2 than those from Im-Cu B. This could be due to the strong electron-donating capacity of AcGlu groups on Im-Cu A. Then, the catalytic mechanism on Im-Cu A is revealed by DFT calculations. The simulated mode structure is formed by adsorbed CO2 on Im-Cu A and free CO3 2– (Fig. 6 a). The relative energy profiles for the carboxylative cyclization reaction and the intercepted minima as well as the transition states are shown in Fig. 5b [26]. Accordingly, Im-Cu A and CO3 2– played synergistic roles in the activation of CO2 and NH group. Based on the analysis of experimental data and DFT calculations, the detailed reaction processes are shown in Fig. 5b and 6 [52]. The catalytic process of Im-Cu A initiated by the adsorption and activation of CO2 on the N site of imidazolium heterocycle (Int0 ). C–H has higher bond energy than that of NH. Therefore, CO3 2– prefers to interact with the α-H of NH on 5a to form the complex Int1 with HCO3 –. The energy barrier of the transition state TS1 is calculated to be 0.62 eV. Later, C atom of the activated CO2 electrophilically attacks NH group of 5a via the transition state TS2 with an energy barrier of 0.31 eV, yielding Int2 containing NCO2. After that, CuCl4 2− stabilized by AcGlu groups interacts with the C≡C triple bond to form Int3 with CH2 C = CH. In this step, the transition state TS3 is fully characterized with an energy barrier of 0.33 eV. The following step involves the ring-closing of the carbonate ion species of Int3 to form a five-membered ring Int4 . The energy barrier for the ring-closing step is calculated to be 0.25 eV. And HCO3 – is activated by CuCl2 − to form Int5 with HCuCl2 −, the transition state TS5 is fully characterized with an energy barrier of 0.47 eV. Then, H on HCuCl2 − interacts with C = CH to form Int6 with C = CH2. In this step, the transition state TS3 is fully characterized with an energy barrier of 0.38 eV. Finally, the target product 6a is obtained and the catalytic cycle ends with the regeneration of CO3 2– and Im-Cu A for the next catalytic cycle (Int7 ). The structural parameters of CO2 adsorbed in different configurations across the reaction pathway were presented in Table S6. The energy barrier for proton-delocalization of the NH stage was remarkably higher than that for intramolecular cyclization and proton migration from HCuCl2 − to, C = CH suggested that proton-delocalization of the NH stage was the rate-determining step of the overall catalytic reaction. In summary, the cyclization reaction of CO2 with 5a involved five main steps as shown in Fig. 6b: (1) the activation of CO2 and 5a with the imidazolium and AcGlu- units in Im-Cu A (intermediate A, B), (2) the proton migration from 5a to CO3 2– (intermediate C), (3) the activation of C≡C triple bond of 5a with copper catalytic species (intermediate D), (4) the intramolecular ring-closing of the carbonate (intermediate E), (5) the proton demetallization of HCO3 – (product F). The electron donating imidazolium and AcGlu units are key to the enhanced the long-term stability and superior performance of Im-Cu A. Based on the results of experiments and DFT calculations, we advocate a novel catalyst design strategy that leverages absorption/activation of CO2, activation of propargylamines, and stabilization of metal catalyst species to efficiently convert them into high-value chemicals. This strategy unfolds in two pivotal steps. Firstly, the catalyst's strong donor oxygen/carbon LA-LB moieties facilitate robust intermolecular/intramolecular interactions, activating the substrates. Secondly, in order to increase the stability of the catalysts, suitable coordination sites were used to inhibit the inactivation of the catalytic species during the catalytic process. In essence, catalysts featuring optimally co-coordinated LA-LB sites not only deliver outstanding performance but also offer chemically adaptable frameworks for precise tuning of their functional properties. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have developed a long-term stable highly-efficient multi-active site Cu catalyst (Im-Cu A) co-coordinated with AcGlu and 2-methyl-imidazolium moieties. 2-Oxazolidinone was synthesized by Im-Cu A-catalyzed cyclization reaction of CO2 and propargylamine with an exciting TOF of 880 h−1, meanwhile, Im-Cu A demonstrated good stability across various temperatures, with the catalytic activity hardly decays even after 20 replicates. A gram-scale experiment was conducted to validate the practical scalability of the Im-Cu A catalyst in this reaction. The experimental and DFT calculations suggested that both AcGlu and 2-methyl-imidazolium units serve as auxiliary sites for absorbing/activating CO2, activating propargylamines, and stabilizing Cu catalytic centers. Meanwhile, it was found that the N atom on 2-methyl-imidazolium heterocycle is the most favorable site for CO2 absorption/activation. The adsorption energy of CuCl4 2− on metal sites was calculated to be 1.49 eV, which revealed that the AcGlu and 2-methyl-imidazolium moieties in Im-Cu A was favorable for the stabilization of catalytic centers. Compared with Im-Cu B without Ac-protecting groups, the catalytic activity of Im-Cu A is significant enhanced in the cyclization reaction of CO2 and propargylamines. This demonstrates that the catalytic activity of the catalyst Im-Cu A with Ac-protecting groups can be improved in CO2 transformations. The energy barrier for proton-delocalization of the NH stage was remarkably higher than that for intramolecular cyclization and proton migration step, suggested that this stage was the rate-determining step. This strategy on design high-performance catalysts with the functions of reaction substrates activation and catalytic centers stabilization is very promising for the breakthrough development of CO2 conversion. coredata.dc:description: The conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2) and propargylamines to 2-oxazolidinones is an essential reaction in industry, but efficiently activating both feedstocks remains a huge challenge for majority of catalysts. Herein, we developed a long-term stable copper catalyst, co-coordinated with sugar acetates (acetylglucose, AcGlu) and 2-methyl-imidazolium (Im-Cu A). This catalyst features multi-active site, enabling it to efficiently capture and activate CO2, activate propargylamines, and stabilize the catalyst species simultaneously. As expected, 2-oxazolidinone was synthesized by this cyclization reaction with an exciting turnover frequency of 880 h−1, which is around 180 times higher than that of CuCl2. Moreover, the catalytic activity of Im-Cu A did not decrease even after 20 replicates, which is exceptionally rare for homogeneous catalysts. Density functional theory calculations indicate that the electron-donating AcGlu and 2-methyl-imidazolium units facilitate electrons transport from Im-Cu A to CO2. Moreover, the high electron density of AcGlu and 2-methyl-imidazolium groups is believed to play a crucial role in the long-term stability across various temperatures and excellent catalytic performance of Im-Cu A. This represents a significant advancement in the development of a highly stable copper catalyst with multi-active site that effectively activates all reaction substrates. This strategy could improve the development of metal catalysts with sustained superior performance for CO2 conversion.

coredata.dc:title: Integrated activation and conversion of CO2 and propargylamine by a robust multi-active site copper catalyst
